participants: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire

messages.message: hey! @lydia @paul @georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire @Ashish @Heymian on the topic of the next release date - I would love to push it back by 1-2 weeks for BAML requirements, but I think there is also an FRB deadline to work with (though I'm not sure exactly when that is).

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: We don't have a hard deadline with FRB but shared that the project will wrap sometime near the end of February. So as long as we can push the latest changes to FRB sometime early/mid Feb we should be fine to QA and finish the POC.
Don’t have a hard deadline for C1 either. I think we mentioned that we would have a build for them in Jan, but no exact date. @paul for his thoughts on this.
In that case, would love a code freeze of Feb 3. Gives us 4 weeks in the new year
that would mean a tape-out of Feb 14-ish?

We pushed the deliverable of client-side encryption for C1 from December to January. I’d like to have some good reasoning to present them before pushing back into February, especially since we just missed the last deployment date we’d committed to with them.
In this scenario, they wouldn’t get the client side encryption stuff until the week of Feb 15?

What are the issues with staying on the current timeline?  Is it possible to start the BAML contract 1 month later?  I would like to avoid changes to our release schedule since the next release is around Feb 20th.
missing the date effectively extends the BAML contract 3 months + whatever date we deliver
(effectively, it’s an opportunity cost of $125k per 3 months)
beyond that, it’s just the customer expectations that were previously set with BAML — unfortunate that they were set without conferring with the team, but there’s definitely a little juggling to do
right now i think we’re just trying to figure out the overall costs of missing one or some of these commitments

I see, why is it effectively extending the BAML contract by 3 months?  Is that how our contract is written?

I thought it would extend it by the final date of when all the issues were resolved and shipped.
which would push it out by a month.

@shaunak that’s a great question — so our contract effective date has already started (it started the day the contract was signed). The deadline for the bug fixes was 3 months after the start date. So if we deliver the last fix 3 months + 1 day post execution, the contract is extended by 3 months + 1 day
if we deliver a month after the feb deadline, it’s a 4 month extension, etc
So effectively it is 1 more month.  We can’t deliver to them before Feb 15th anyway.
We can also take this offline as well involving everyone who wants has ideas / requirements

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: Let's take this offline, we have a meeting to discuss this scheduled for Monday - I'll add you.
:thumbsup_all:
either way, appreciate everyone talking through the tradeoffs and helping us understand what can be shipped when
there are some valuable takeaways here that we’ll be able to avoid in the future

@paul @georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire overall, just to emphasize on the release process, customer success team should essentially drive the dates around the releases and not engineering since customer success has the context on the promises being made to customers. For example, how does c1 feel about if we push back the encryption deliverable again?
I’d like to make sure that’s the only option before asking them to push it back again
I agree @paul. We should have more clarity on Monday.
